docs.title: Interactive Course Portal
docs.text: Welcome to your complete physics learning environment. Explore modules, practice problems, simulations, and reviews — all in one place.

docs.title: 🚀 Start Here
docs.text: - :rocket: **Begin Learning**    ---   Start with the fundamentals of 1D and 2D motion using calculus.    [Start Week 1 →](week1/index.md)  - :book: **View Syllabus**    ---   Course structure, grading, expectations, and weekly schedule.    [Open Syllabus →](syllabus.md)  - :mag: **Search the Course**    ---   Instantly find any formula, example, or topic using the search bar.    Use the 🔍 icon in the top-right.

docs.title: 📘 Course Modules
docs.text: - :one: **Week 1 — Kinematics**    ---   Motion in 1D, derivatives, integrals, free fall, displacement, velocity, acceleration.    [Go to Week 1 →](week1/index.md)  - :two: **Week 2 — Vectors & 2D Motion**    ---   Components, unit vectors, dot product, projectile motion, circular motion.    [Go to Week 2 →](week2/index.md)  - :three: **Week 3 — Forces & Newton’s Laws**    ---   Dynamics, free-body diagrams, friction, tension, Newton’s laws, applications.    [Go to Week 3 →](week3/index.md)  - :four: **Week 4 — Work & Energy**    ---   Work-energy theorem, kinetic & potential energy, conservative vs. non-conservative forces.    [Go to Week 4 →](week4/index.md)  - :five: **Week 5 — Momentum & Collisions**    ---   Impulse-momentum theorem, elastic/inelastic collisions, center of mass.    [Go to Week 5 →](week5/index.md)  - :six: **Week 6 — Rotational Motion**    ---   Rotational kinematics & dynamics, torque, moment of inertia.    [Go to Week 6 →](week6/index.md)  - :seven: **Week 7 — SHM & Gravitation**    ---   Springs, pendulums, oscillations, universal gravitation, orbital motion.    [Go to Week 7 →](week7/index.md)  - :eight: **Week 8 — Thermodynamics**    ---   Temperature, heat transfer, ideal gases, first law of thermodynamics.    [Go to Week 8 →](week8/index.md)

docs.title: 🧪 Interactive Tools
docs.text: - :chart_with_upwards_trend: **Simulations**    ---   Test motion graphs, forces, energy, and waves with interactive demos.    *Coming soon.*  - :pencil2: **Practice Problems**    ---   Challenge problems with instant solutions to test your understanding.    *Coming soon.*  - :zap: **Exam Reviews**    ---   Guided review modules for each exam with summaries & practice quizzes.    *Coming soon.*

docs.title: 🧩 About the Course
docs.text:
This course combines physics + calculus to help you master:

  • motion in 1D & 2D
  • forces & Newton’s laws
  • rotational dynamics
  • energy & momentum
  • oscillations & waves
  • thermodynamics

You will learn to: - model physical systems - solve problems using derivatives & integrals - build intuition with diagrams & graphs - analyze real-world phenomena

# 🎉 Ready to Begin? [Start Week 1 →](week1/index.md){ .md-button .md-button--primary .md-button--large }

docs.title: Syllabus
docs.text: Content coming soon.

docs.title: 🧭 Week 1 — Units, Dimensions, & 1D Kinematics (with Calculus)
docs.text:
Welcome to Week 1! This module is designed so that you can teach yourself physics even if you missed class — or want to build a stronger foundation for the rest of the course.

By the end of Week 1, you’ll understand:

  • Units, dimensions, and physical meaning
  • Position, velocity, acceleration
  • Derivatives in motion
  • Integrals in motion
  • Free fall
  • Graph interpretation
  • Real-world problem solving

docs.title: 🎯 Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this module, you will be able to:

  • Convert units and analyze dimensions
  • Use calculus to transition between position, velocity, and acceleration
  • Interpret motion graphs
  • Solve constant and non-constant acceleration problems
  • Model real motion with integrals and derivatives
  • Apply free-fall equations correctly

docs.title: SI Base Units
docs.text: Quantity Unit Symbol Length meter m Mass kilogram kg Time second s Temperature kelvin K Electric current ampere A

docs.title: Dimensions
docs.text:
Dimensions express the type of quantity.

Examples:

\[ \text{Velocity}: [L][T^{-1}] \] \[ \text{Acceleration}: [L][T^{-2}] \] \[ \text{Force}: [M][L][T^{-2}] \]

📌 If dimensions don’t match on both sides of an equation, the equation is wrong.

docs.title: ✨ Example: Dimensional Analysis
docs.text:
Is [ v = 3t + 7x ] valid?

  • Left side: \([L/T]\)
  • Right side: \(3t \rightarrow [T]\), \(7x \rightarrow [L]\)

❌ Invalid. Units don’t match, so this equation cannot describe motion.

docs.title: 🔧 Unit Conversions (Factor-Label Method)
docs.text:
Example:

Convert 60 mph → m/s

\[ 60\frac{\text{mi}}{\text{hr}} \cdot \frac{1609\ \text{m}}{1\ \text{mi}} \cdot \frac{1\ \text{hr}}{3600\ \text{s}} = 26.8\ \text{m/s} \]

Unit consistency = physics success.

docs.title: Definitions
docs.text:
\[ v(t) = \frac{dx}{dt} \] \[ a(t) = \frac{dv}{dt} \]

These come directly from calculus.

  • Velocity = rate of change of position
  • Acceleration = rate of change of velocity

docs.title: 🔎 Example Function
docs.text:
Let:

\[ x(t) = t^3 - 4t + 2 \]

Then:

\[ v(t) = 3t^2 - 4 \] \[ a(t) = 6t \]

Interpretation:

  • Velocity changes quadratically
  • Acceleration increases linearly → motion speeds up faster over time

docs.title: 📘 3. Derivatives in Kinematics
docs.text: Derivatives describe instantaneous rates of change.

docs.title: Example (Try This!)
docs.text:
\[ x(t) = 5t^2 - 3t + 8 \]

Velocity:

\[ v(t) = 10t - 3 \]

Acceleration:

\[ a(t) = 10 \]

Acceleration is constant → parabola position + linear velocity.

docs.title: 📘 4. Integrals in Kinematics
docs.text: Integrals reconstruct motion when velocity or acceleration is known.

docs.title: If acceleration is known:
docs.text: \[ v(t) = \int a(t)\, dt \]

docs.title: If velocity is known:
docs.text: \[ x(t) = \int v(t)\, dt \]

docs.title: 🌟 Constant Acceleration (Very Important)
docs.text:
If acceleration \(a\) is constant:

\[ v(t) = v_0 + at \] \[ x(t) = x_0 + v_0 t + \frac{1}{2}at^2 \]

These will appear everywhere in physics.

docs.title: 🌟 Non-Constant Acceleration
docs.text:
Example:

\[ a(t) = 4t \] \[ v(t) = \int 4t\,dt = 2t^2 + C \]

Use initial conditions to solve for \(C\).

docs.title: 📘 5. Free Fall
docs.text:
In free fall, acceleration is constant:

\[ a = g = 9.8\ \text{m/s}^2 \]

Velocity:

\[ v(t) = gt + v_0 \]

Position:

\[ x(t) = x_0 + v_0 t + \frac{1}{2}gt^2 \]

If dropped: [ v_0 = 0 ]

docs.title: 📘 6. Graph Interpretation
docs.text: Understanding graphs is one of the MOST important physics skills.

docs.title: 📈 Position → Velocity
docs.text: Velocity = slope of position graph.

docs.title: 📉 Velocity → Acceleration
docs.text: Acceleration = slope of velocity graph.

docs.title: 🧭 Velocity → Displacement
docs.text: Displacement = area under velocity graph.

docs.title: Example 2 — Dropped Object
docs.text: A ball is dropped from 20 m.

docs.title: Position:
docs.text:
\[ x = 20 - \frac{1}{2}(9.8)(2^2) = 0.4\ \text{m} \]

Just above the ground.

docs.title: 📝 8. Practice Problems
docs.text: Try these before checking solutions:
A car starts from rest and accelerates at 4 m/s² for 5 seconds. Find the distance traveled.
A ball is thrown upward at 12 m/s. Find its max height.
Convert 45 mph to m/s.

docs.title: 🧪 9. Mini Quiz (Check Your Understanding)
docs.text:
1. If velocity is the derivative of position, acceleration is the… ▶ derivative of velocity

2. True or False: velocity can be zero while acceleration is nonzero. ▶ True

3. A ball dropped has initial velocity… ▶ \(0\ \text{m/s}\)

4. If \(a(t)=10\), velocity is what type of function? ▶ Linear

docs.title: Must-Know Skills
docs.text:
• Read position/velocity/acceleration graphs
  • Perform derivatives & integrals in motion
  • Apply free-fall equations
  • Check dimensional consistency
  • Convert units reliably

docs.title: 🎉 Excellent Work!
docs.text:
You’ve completed Week 1 — the foundation of all motion in physics. You're ready for Week 2: Vectors, Components, and 2D Motion.

➡️ Continue to Week 2
